awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, the Environmental Chemical Sciences Program of the Division of Chemistry is funding Professor Mary Jane Shultz of Tufts University to investigate environmental reactions related to ammonia and acids. Synthesis of ammonia from atmospheric nitrogen has been called the greatest invention of the 20th century; indeed, it is responsible for feeding half the world?s population. It also consumes more than 2% of the World?s energy.  Unfortunately, only 15% of the ammonia created and converted into fertilizer is useful for food production. As much as 50% of the ammonia produced ends up in the air or in water supplies. The fate and impact of the ammonia released into the atmosphere is largely unknown however, mitigating the loss of ammonia produced could have a major economic impact on food producers as well as reducing negative effects of runoff on water supplies. Modeling results suggest a catalytic role for ammonia in transforming sulfur oxides into particles that generate clouds. Clouds in turn modulate Earth's radiation balance. Understanding particle formation is one of the grand challenges associated with climate and weather modeling. This work is aimed at understanding the role of ammonia in the environment, especially in terms of energy consumption, food production and clean water supplies.  The project is also expected to contribute to the technological workforce; students gain experience with inventing and applying forefront tools for probing surfaces. Data are shared with local secondary schools through the chemistry department COOP program; the Shultz laboratory is a host for COOP students.

This project combines emerging spectroscopic techniques with surface science to probe ammonia-surface interactions. Surfaces play an outsized role both in soil-ammonia and ammonia-atmospheric-aerosol interactions. Probing complex mixtures that exist on these surfaces presents a challenge to most traditional surface science techniques. There is one technique that meets the challenge: nonlinear, surface-specific vibrational spectroscopy coupled with nonlinear interferometry. Applying this technique to soil and aerosol interfaces is expected to yield insight into interactions that impact water and air quality. Additionally, a deeper understanding of soil chemistry could lead to improved fertilizer formulations for controlled release impacting both food and water supplies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Overview:

The key outcomes of this National Science Foundation funded project result from fundamental physical chemistry guiding development of materials to address the impact of ammonia on the environment. The Haber-Bosch process that converts atmospheric nitrogen into ammonia is probably the most impactful process devised: estimates are that half the world’s population is alive due to this crop production enhancing process. Like many advances, ammonia production has a down-side. About half the applied ammonia (or derivatives such as urea) is lost from the soil due to release either to the waterways as aqueous run-off or to the atmosphere as a gas. For both destinations, loss prevention is preferable to impact mitigation. The outcomes of this project contribute to prevention by (a) developing ultranano (~ 1 nm) oxide particles that can adsorb ammonia, potentially releasing it only upon a signal from the growing distal root tip, (b) creating a macro porous scaffold to immobilize the nanoparticles, and (c) advancing recently invented instrumentation to probe the guiding underlying chemistry at the molecular level. Each of these is summarized in the next section.

 

Intellectual Merit:

(a) Developing materials for environmental applications is guided by the adage: first do no harm. The project thus focused on titania. The global production of titania was 9.5 million metric tons in 2022. It is used in toothpaste, skim milk, medicinal tablet filler, paint pigments and thousands of additional products. If there were deleterious impacts, they would be well known. Titania has three major polymorphs, and its chemistry is complex. The project approach consisted of making ultrasmall particles containing a few hundred TiO2 units. As such they are more like large molecules than polymorphic solids. Using a variety of measurement techniques (UV-Vis, hard x-ray, and Raman) it was shown that at such small scale, titania particles are reproducible, have a single polymorph truncated bipyramid morphology known as anatase, and are amenable to modification using molecular chemical techniques. Most significantly, particles can be modified with a single atom of an Earth-abundant (e.g. Cu, Mo, Mn, Ni) to control attachment to the surface. Since the modifier can be chosen at will, the future direction is to select the modifier that adsorbs ammonia (or urea, etc.) tightly enough to prevent aqueous or gas-phase release, yet weakly enough to release ammonia upon signal from the growing root.

 

(b) Ultrasmall particles are potentially quite mobile. To store ammonia, they should remain where they are applied. The project thus devised a microporous scaffold to immobilize the particles. Two key scaffold properties are that the nanoparticles remain robustly attached under environmental conditions and that water readily flows through the pores. The first eliminates any organic material since titania is an excellent photo-oxidizer. This project thus focused on glass: SiO2. The second requires that scaffold pores are sufficiently large to support facile water movement. Given the surface tension of water, this means micron size.[1] Furthermore, the scaffold must also be environmentally compatible. The project thus focused on silica: SiO2, a major component of the Earth’s crust. Generating the scaffold leverages growth habits of ice: ice growth excludes solutes to the grain boundaries. An outcome of this project is a method to create a uniaxial scaffold with this morphology. The method is based on freeze casting: generating a high concentration silicate solution followed by rapid, uniform freeze front velocity across a several cm2 area.

(c) Both (a) and (b) were guided by technical equipment consisting of a newly invented nonlinear interferometer created to probe complex, dynamic interfaces buried interfaces at the molecular level. While interferometers of various designs are well known, a nonlinear interferometer is unique in that the input consists of two different frequency beams while the output contains a third beam with a frequency that is the sum of the two inputs. In logic circuits, this would be an and gate. The sum process occurs only in an environment that lacks inversion symmetry: all surfaces met this requirement. This project employed this instrument to probe interactions at the silicate-nanoparticle interface.

 

Broader Impacts: Feeding the World while protecting the environment is clearly a broader impact. Beyond that, the project supported development of the scientific workforce including members of under-represented groups (Hispanic and women). More broadly, the message that chemistry can be leveraged to solve broad issues while anticipating unintended consequences is important for all associated with this project.

 

Within the narrower field, the project provides guidelines for nanoparticle engineering to support chosen transformations, principles for creating macro porous materials, and instrumentation to probe complex interfaces. Three patents were created.


[1] Mesoporous silica is readily available; however, the pores are nanoscale. Nanoscale pores require high pressure for water flow.
